case_name: State of Assam v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1100 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1100 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 26, 1962 of Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 489 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 26, 1962 of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 489 of 1961.

facts.text: In 1954, Assam Government took possession of lands of respondent and others in Kamrup District for Pagdalia embankment construction.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954, the Assam Government took possession of the lands of the respondent and several other persons situated in the District of Kamrup for the construction of the Pagdalia embankment.

facts.text: Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Ordinance, 1955 (No. 2 of 1955) passed.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Ordinance, 1955 (Assam Ordinance No. 2 of 1955) was passed enabling the State Government to acquire lands...

facts.text: Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Act, 1955 (No. 6 of 1955) passed on April 11, 1955 with President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance was replaced by the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Act, 1955 (Assam Act No. 6 of 1955) which was passed on April 11, 1955 with the assent of the President.

facts.text: In April 1956, State Government passed order acquiring lands taken in 1954 for Pagdalia embankment under s.3 of Ordinance No.2 of 1955 (mistake, meant Act No.6).

anchor.surface_text: In April 1956, the State Government passed an order in writing acquiring the lands taken over in 1954 for the construction of the Pagdalia embankment under s. 3 of Ordinance No. 2 of 1955.

facts.text: On April 26, 1956, respondent served with notice of acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the reference to the Ordinance was a mistake and the acquisition was made under Act No. 6 of 1955. On April 26, 1956, the respondent was served with the notice of the acquisition.

facts.text: On September 10, 1959, Deputy Commissioner, Kamrup quashed April 1956 order and directed fresh proceedings under Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated September 10, 1959, the Deputy Commissioner, Kamrup acting on behalf of the State Government quashed the Order dated April 19, 1956 and directed that fresh acquisition proceedings under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 should be started.

facts.text: Some lands for Pagdalia embankment acquired under Land Acquisition Act with full compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order, some of the lands required for the Pagdalia embankment were acquired under the Land Acquisition Act on payment of full compensation.

facts.text: Draft notification for respondent's lands under Land Acquisition Act sent but proposal dropped.

anchor.surface_text: A draft notification for the acquisition of the respondents lands under the Land Acquisition Act was sent by the Collector of Kamrup to the Assam Government for approval, but this proposal was eventually dropped.

facts.text: Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control Validation Act, 1959 (No. 21 of 1960) passed on May 27, 1960 with President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1960. the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Validation Act, 1959 (Assam Act No. 21 of 1960) was passed with the assent of the President.

facts.text: In November 1960, State Government passed acquisition order for respondent's lands under s.3 of Act No.21 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In November 1960. the State Government passed an order for the acquisition of the respondents lands under s. 3 of the Assam Acquisition of Land for Flood Control and Prevention of Erosion Act. It was common case...

facts.text: On November 6, 1960, Collector of Kamrup served notice on respondent of acquisition order and to submit compensation claim.

anchor.surface_text: On November 6, 1960, the Collector of Kamrup served a notice upon the respondent informing him of the acquisition order and asking him to submit his claim for compensation.

facts.text: On September 30, 1961, respondent filed writ petition in Assam High Court challenging Act No.6 of 1955 and Act No.21 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1961, the respondent filed a writ petition in the Assam High Court asking for an order declaring Act No. 6 of 1955 and Act No. 21 of 1960 to be invalid...

facts.text: Assam High Court allowed the writ petition and issued mandamus directing State not to give effect to notices under Act No.21 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition and issued a writ of mandamus directing the State Government to forbear from giving effect to the notices issued under Act No. 21 of 1960.

facts.text: Present appeal filed under certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal has been filed under a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: It was common case before High Court that 1960 acquisition under s.3 of Act No.21 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It was common case before the High Court that this acquisition was made under s. 3 of Act No. 21 of 1960.

facts.text: Respondent challenged validity of Act No.6 of 1955 and Act No.21 of 1960 as contravening Arts.14 and 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the validity of Act No. 6 of 1955 and Act No 21 of 1960 on the ground that they contravened Arts. 14 and 31(2) of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court held Act No.6 of 1955 violative of Art.31(2) pre-Fourth Amendment and not protected by Art.31A.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that (1) Act No. 6 of 1955 was violative of Art. 31(2) of the Constitution as it stood before the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act and was not protected by Art. 31A...

facts.text: High Court held s.3 of Act No.21 of 1960 not independent law, falls with invalid Act No.6.

anchor.surface_text: ...and (2) s. 3 of Act No. 21 of 1960 declaring that certain lands would be deemed to be validly acquired under the earlier Act was not a law providing for acquisition of land independently of the earlier Act and as the earlier Act was invalid, the later Act fell with it.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed, upholding High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Lands situated in District of Kamrup.

anchor.surface_text: ...lands of the respondent and several other persons situated in the District of Kamrup...

facts.text: Respondent's lands not acquired under Land Acquisition Act, proposal dropped.

anchor.surface_text: ...acquisition of the respondents lands under the Land Acquisition Act... but this proposal was eventually dropped.

facts.text: Appellants argued Acts not violative of Arts.14 and 31(2), protected by 31A and 31(5)(b)(ii).

anchor.surface_text: Before us, counsel for the appellants submitted that the two Acts were not violative of Arts. 14 and 31(2) and were, in any event, protected by Arts.31A and 31(5)(b)(ii).

facts.text: No counsel for respondent, assisted by amicus curiae R.L. Iyengar.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was not represented by counsel, but we have had the advantage of the argument of Mr. Iyengar who assisted as amicus curiae.
The respondent challenged the validity of Act No. 6 of 1955 and Act No 21 of 1960 on the ground that they contravened Arts. 14 and 31(2) of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Act No. 6 protected by Art. 31A only for agrarian reform laws like Kochuni case

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. It is number well settled that Art. 31A 1  a  envisages only laws concerning agrarian reform. In Kochunis case 1 , the Court...

arguments.claim: Act No. 6 not protected by Art. 31A as not agrarian reform, purely expropriatory

anchor.surface_text: In the light of these decisions, we must hold that Act No. 6 of 1955 is number a law concerning agrarian reform and -is number protected by Art. 31A. The Act is a purely expropriatory measure.

arguments.claim: Art. 31(5)(b)(ii) saves police powers but not eminent domain acquisitions requiring compensation

anchor.surface_text: If Art. 31 5  b  ii  is regarded as a saving clause with regard to the police power of the State... private property cannot be appropriated, to public use without payment of compensation.

arguments.claim: Act No. 6 violates Art. 31(2) pre-Fourth Amendment as compensation not just equivalent

arguments.claim: Classification under Act 6 has no reasonable relation to object of acquisition

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the classification of land required for works... has number reasonable relation to the object sought to be achieved. viz., acquisition of the land by the State.

arguments.claim: Act 21 not independent legislation, deems acquisition under invalid Act 6, hence invalid

anchor.surface_text: As Assam Act No. 6 of 1955 is invalid, the deemed acquisition under Assam Act No. 21 of 1960 is equally invalid. The State legislature has number power to enact that an acquisition

arguments.claim: Act 6 supersedes Land Acquisition Act under Art. 254(2)

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants contends that in view of Art. 254 2  of the Constitution Assam Act No. 6 of 1955 supersedes the Land Acquisition Act, 1894

arguments.court_reasoning: Not decided as other grounds suffice

arguments.claim: High Court did not opine on Art. 14 violation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number express any opinion on the question whether the two Acts were I violative of Art. 14.

holdings.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 is not a law concerning agrarian reform and is not protected by Art. 31A.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of these decisions, we must hold that Act No. 6 of 1955 is not a law concerning agrarian reform and -is not protected by Art. 31A. The Act is a purely expropriatory measure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents (Kochuni, Ranjit Singh, P.V. Mudaliar) limiting Art.31A to agrarian reform laws; Act 6 is purely expropriatory for flood control, unrelated to land tenures or intermediaries.

holdings.text: Clause 5(b)(ii) of Art. 31 did not protect laws for acquisition of properties from the operation of clause 2 as it stood before the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have come to the conclusion that cl. 5 b ii did not protect laws for acquisition of properties from the operation of cl. 2 as it stood before the Constitution Fourth Amendment Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation distinguishing police power (destruction/temporary takings without compensation in emergencies) from eminent domain (acquisition requiring compensation); reconciles prior SC cases; cl.5(b)(ii) saves only non-acquisitory measures.

holdings.text: Act No. 6 of 1955 does not ensure payment of a just equivalent of the land appropriated and is violative of Art. 31(2) as it stood before the Fourth Amendment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion. Act No. 6 of 1955 does not ensure payment of a just equivalent of the land appropriated and is violative of Art. 31 2 as it stood before the Fourth Amendment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Bela Banerjee principle requiring 'just equivalent/full indemnification'; s.6 compensation capped at illusory multiple of land revenue unrelated to market value; pretence of considering value meaningless due to cap.

holdings.text: Assam Act No. 6 of 1955 is violative of Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that Assam Act No. 6 of 1955 is violative of Art. 14. ... The constitutional guarantee of Art. 14 requires that all persons shall be treated alike in like circumstances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification test: differential treatment (nominal compensation under Act 6 vs market value under LAA for similar flood control purposes) lacks nexus to object of acquisition; follows P.V. Mudaliar.

holdings.text: Assam Act No. 21 of 1960 is not a law providing for acquisition independently of Act No. 6 of 1955; as Act No. 6 is invalid, the deemed acquisition under Act No. 21 is equally invalid.

anchor.surface_text: As Assam Act No. 6 of 1955 is invalid, the deemed acquisition under Assam Act No. 21 of 1960 is equally invalid. The State legislature has no power to enact that an acquisition

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.2 deeming prior takings valid under invalid Act 6; validation act dependent on principal act's validity; legislature cannot deem unconstitutional acquisition valid.

holdings.text: A law for acquisition of property is not protected by cl. 5(b)(ii) of Art. 31 even as it stands after the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that a law for acquisition of property is not protected by cl. 5 b ii of Art. 31 as it now stands after the Constitution Fourth Amendment Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-Fourth Amendment, cl.2 excludes non-transfer deprivations; cl.5(b)(ii) saves only temporary requisitions for emergencies, not permanent acquisitions; consistent with original intent.

anchor.surface_text: In Kochunis case 1 , the Court by a majority decision held that the Madras Marumakkathayam  Removal of Doubts  Act, 1955 which deprived a sthanee of his properties and vested- them in the tarwad companytravened Art. 19 1  f  and was number protected by Art. 31A and that Art. 31A saved laws for agrarian reform only and did number enable the State to divest a proprietor of his estate and vest it in another without reference to any agrarian reform.

precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 31A saves laws for agrarian reform only and does not enable the State to divest a proprietor of his estate and vest it in another without reference to agrarian reform
precedents.cited_holding: the Madras Marumakkathayam Removal of Doubts Act, 1955 contravened Art. 19(1)(f) and was not protected by Art. 31A

anchor.surface_text: In Ranjit Singh State of Punjab 2 , the Court held that the East Punjab Holdings  Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation  Act, 1948 as amended by Act No. 27 of 1960 was protected by Art. 31A, as the general scheme of the Act was definitely agrarian reform and under its provisions something ancillary thereto in the interests of rural economy had to be un- dertaken to give full effect to the reforms.

precedents.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act protected by Art. 31A as agrarian reform

precedents.citation: P. V. Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector, Madras 3

anchor.surface_text: In P. V. Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector, Madras 3 , the Court held that the Land Acquisition  Madras Amendment  Act, 1961 providing for the acquisition of lands for housing scheme was number a law with reference to any agrarian reform and was number protected by Art. 31A.

precedents.case_name: P. V. Mudaliar v. Special Deputy Collector, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Land Acquisition (Madras Amendment) Act, 1961 for housing schemes not protected by Art. 31A

precedents.citation: Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railway Company v. People of the State of Illinois 1

anchor.surface_text: see Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railway Company v. People of the State of Illinois 1 . In the exercise of its eminent domain power, the State may take any property from the owner and may appropriate it for public purposes The police and eminent domain powers are essentially distinct.

precedents.case_name: Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railway Company v. People of the State of Illinois
precedents.cited_proposition: police power allows regulations for public health, morals, safety without compensation; eminent domain requires compensation

anchor.surface_text: In Sweet v.Rechel 2  the validity of an Act to enable the City of Boston to abate a nuisance existing therein and for the preservation of the public health in the City by improving the drainage of the territory was sustained on the ground that the Act provided for payment of just companypensation.

precedents.cited_proposition: act for public health with compensation upheld; property endangering health cannot be taken without compensation

precedents.citation: Delaware W. R. Co. v. Morristown 1

anchor.surface_text: In Delaware W. R. Co. v. Morristown 1  an Ordinance establishing a public hack stand on private property without payment of companypensation was struck down on the ground that assuming that the creation of the public hack stand would be a proper exercise of the police power it did number follow that the due process clause would number safeguard to the owner just companypen- sation for the use of the property.

precedents.case_name: Delaware & W. R. Co. v. Morristown
precedents.cited_proposition: ordinance using private property as public hack stand without compensation invalid under due process

anchor.surface_text: In United States v. Caltex  Philippines  2 , the Court held that numbercompensation was payable by the United States for the destruction by its retreating army of private property to prevent its falling into enemy hands. But the Court recognised that companypensation would be payable for the armys requisitioning of private property for its subsequent use.

precedents.cited_proposition: no compensation for destruction to prevent enemy capture, but yes for requisition and use

anchor.surface_text: as will appear from the following historic incident referred to in Respublica v. Sparhawk 3  We find, indeed, a memorable instance of folly recorded- in the 3 vol. of Clarendons History, where it is mentioned,, that the Lord Mayor of London in 1666.

precedents.cited_proposition: historic example of folly in not destroying property to prevent fire spread

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose and Other 1

anchor.surface_text: We shall number examine our earlier decisions in The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose and Other 1  and Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The SholapurSpinning and Weaving Co.  Pd., and others 1 , where reference was made to the companycepts of eminent domain and police power in relation to cls.

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of Arts. 31(1) and (2); substantial deprivation amounts to taking under Art. 31(2)

precedents.citation: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The SholapurSpinning and Weaving Co.  Pd., and others 1

precedents.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co.

anchor.surface_text: Any substantial abridgment of the rights of ownership including destruction and injurious affection of the property and taking away its possession and enjoyment from the owner amounted to a taking of property within the purview of cl.  2  as interpreted in Subodh Gopals case 1  and Dwarkadas Shrinivass case 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: substantial abridgment of ownership rights amounts to taking under Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: as interpreted in Subodh Gopals case 1  and Dwarkadas Shrinivass case 1 . A law for promotion of public health or for prevention of danger to life or property sometimes has to provide for destruction and impairment of value of private property and the taking of temporary possession of the property by the State.

precedents.cited_proposition: substantial abridgment of ownership rights amounts to taking under Art. 31(2)

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Bela Banerjee and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In The State of West Bengal v. Bela Banerjee and Others 1   the Court held that while the legislature had a discretionary power of laying down the principles which should govern the determination of the amount to be given to the owner for the property appropriated, such principles must ensure that what is determined as payable was a just equivalent of what the owner was deprived of

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Bela Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation principles must ensure just equivalent of property taken
precedents.cited_holding: West Bengal Land Development Act fixing old market value offended Art. 31(2)

precedents.citation: West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd., State of Madras, 1

anchor.surface_text: In West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd., State of Madras, 1 , the Court rejected the companytention that the Madras Electricity Supply Undertakings  Acquisi- tion  Act No. 19 of 1954 was violative of Art. 31 2 , as the appellant did number furnish any material to show that the companypensation payable under the Act was number a just equivalent of the property acquired.

precedents.case_name: West Ramnad Electric Distribution Co. Ltd. v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: no violation of Art. 31(2) without material showing compensation not just equivalent

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar 2

anchor.surface_text: In State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar 2 , the Court held that the Madras Lignite  Acquisition of Land  Act No. 21 of 1953 providing for assessment of companypensation on the basis of the market value of the land prevailing on August 28, 1947 ... offended Art. 31(2)

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. D. Namasivaya Mudaliar
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation based on old market value not just equivalent, violates Art. 31(2)

precedents.citation: P. V. Mudaliar v. Dy. Collector 1

anchor.surface_text: In P. V. Mudaliar v. Dy. Collector 1 , the Court held that the Land Acquisition  Madras Amendment  Act, 1961 providing for the acquisition of lands for housing schemes and laying down principles for fixing companypensation different from those prescribed in the Land Acquisition Act was violative of Art. 14.

precedents.case_name: P. V. Mudaliar v. Deputy Collector
precedents.cited_proposition: different compensation for housing schemes vs other purposes violates Art. 14
precedents.cited_holding: discrimination between lands acquired under different acts without rational basis violates Art. 14
